qas.question: What language had the greatest influence on English?
What was the name of the area in England ruled by the Vikings?
Who argued that the influence of Old Norse caused English to become a clearer, stronger and more direct language?
What parts of English grammar declined as a result of Old Norse influence?
What influence made English more of a synthetic language?
What language had the most impact on other languages?

plausible_answers.text: The eagerness of Vikings in the Danelaw to communicate with their southern Anglo-Saxon neighbors

qas.question: Why did the Vikings stop using complicated word-endings?
What did the Norse language gain clarity and directness from?

context: The influence of <a0_0><b4_0>Old Norse<b4_0/><a0_0/> certainly helped move <b7_0>English<b7_0/> from a synthetic language along the continuum to a more analytic word order, and <b5_0>Old Norse<b5_0/> most likely made a greater impact on the English language than any other language. <b6_0>The eagerness of Vikings in <a1_0>the Danelaw<a1_0/> to communicate with their southern Anglo-Saxon neighbors<b6_0/> produced a friction that led to the erosion of the complicated inflectional <a3_0>word-endings<a3_0/>. <a2_0>Simeon Potter<a2_0/> notes: “No less far-reaching was the influence of Scandinavian upon the inflexional endings of English in hastening that wearing away and leveling of grammatical forms which gradually spread from north to south. It was, after all, a salutary influence. The gain was greater than the loss. There was a gain in directness, in clarity, and in strength.”
